title-group.article-title: Using Agrawal integral equation to study the glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics of exfoliated nano-composites synthesized by vinyl acetate and organic montmorillonite

article-meta.aff: 1College of Wood Science and Technology, Nanjing Forestry University, Jiangsu, China

3Key State Laboratory of New Display and System Applications and Sino-Swedish Microsystem Integration Technology Center, College of Automation and Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Hui-wang Cui, Key State Laboratory of New Display and System Applications and Sino-Swedish Microsystem Integration Technology Center, College of Automation and Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai 200072, China Email: cuihuiwang@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: To study the glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics, the exfoliated nano-composites synthesized by vinyl acetate (VAc) and organic montmorillonite (OMMT) through different processes were investigated by dynamic mechanical analysis. Different synthesis processes and OMMT had significant effect on their dynamic mechanical properties. They brought combined effect on the modulus, loss tangent, and glass transition temperature (Tg). OMMT could lower PVAc’s Tg, so improved PVAc’s low temperature resistance. PVAc–OMMT was a homogeneous amorphous linear polymer and it appeared the cold crystallization phenomenon. The glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics were first analyzed using the Agrawal integral equation. The kinetic parameters, including the kinetics mechanism function, the linear fit equation, the linearly dependent coefficient, the activation energy, the frequency factor, the mechanism, the reaction order, and the kinetic compensation effect equation, were obtained.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a natural, cheap nano-material, montmorillonite (MMT) and its organized product – organic montmorillonite (OMMT) have been applied in polymers for many years,1,2 such as polyacrylate ester,3,4 poly (methyl methacrylate),5,6 polyurethane,7,8 epoxy,9,10 polycarbonate,11,12 polyethylene,13 polypropylene,14 and coatings2,15. In our previous work, with violent stirring, low-OMMT content, high-polymerization temperature, reasonable polymerization time, and suitable proportion of water in the synthesis, different exfoliated nano-composites were prepared by vinyl acetate (VAc) and OMMT.16–20 Their structure, dispersion, particles, rheology, and static tensile were investigated in detail. In this article, their dynamic mechanical properties were the points, especially the glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics.

Dynamic mechanical property is always to measure the variation law of materials’ changing with temperature under a certain frequency, or changing with frequency or deformation at a certain temperature. It can reflect the internal structure and the molecular motion law of materials. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) is used to do this. It is an important measure to study the viscoelastic materials. From its spectra, the dynamic elastic modulus, loss modulus, loss tangent, and other parameters are available. They can reflect the damping properties for materials. In fact, He et al.21–24 had done some similar work before. They used dynamic torsional vibration methods and Avrami theory to study the curing kinetics of some thermosetting resins. Thus, in this article, to study the glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics, PVAc–OMMT was polymerized by VAc and OMMT25,26 through different synthesis processes. In the synthesis, OMMT was 2% of VAc.16–20 Their DMA tests were carried out. Their glass transition and cold crystallization were studied, and how to use the Agrawal integral equation to follow their kinetics was also first introduced in detail.

sec.title: Samples
sec.p: In this study, 1.00 g of OMMT was immersed into 25.00 g of VAc for 24 h. They were then mixed with 70.00 g of 10% polyvinyl alcohol solution, 0.50 g of alkylphenol polyoxyethylene (10) ether, 3.75 g of 10% ammonium persulfate solution, 6.25 g of sodium lauryl sulfate, and 250 g (200 g, 150 g, 100 g, 50 g) of water while vigorously stirring for 8 h. When the mixture became a homogeneous emulsion, the temperature rose to 70°C. While vigorously stirring, 3.75 g of 10% ammonium persulfate solution and 25.00 g of VAc were gradually added into the homogeneous emulsion in 6 h (5 h, 4 h, 3 h, 2 h) for polymerization. Subsequently, the temperature rose to 85–90°C, the emulsion further polymerized for 0.5–1 h. After polymerization, the temperature dropped to below 50°C, 4.00 g of ethanol, 3.00 g of water, 0.30 g of sodium benzoate, 0.18 g of sodium bicarbonate, and 6.00 g of di-n-butyl phthalate were added into the emulsion. Finally, PVAc–OMMT-A (PVAc–OMMT-B, PVAc–OMMT-C, PVAc–OMMT-D, PVAc–OMMT-E) was obtained. Here, we used A, B, C, D, and E, respectively, to correspond to the different synthesis processes with different polymerization time and different proportion of water. PVAc-A, PVAc-B, PVAc-C, PVAc-D, and PVAc-E were also synthesized by the same processes as PVAc–OMMT, but without OMMT.

sec.title: Dynamic mechanical analysis
sec.p: The samples were made into circular films. Their diameter was 10 mm, and their thickness was 0.5 mm. After drying them to constant weight at room temperature, they were tested by NETZSCH DMA 242C DMA through compression model under 10 Hz of frequency, rising temperature from 0°C to 200°C at a rate of 5°C min−1, 120 µm of the maximum amplitude, 8 N of the maximum dynamic force, and 2 N of the minimum static force.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
From our previous work,16–20 we know that the different synthesis processes had little effect on the structure of PVAc and PVAc–OMMT. PVAc–OMMT was an exfoliated nano-composite. From PVAc-A to PVAc-E and from PVAc–OMMT-A to PVAc–OMMT-E, their Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy spectra were nearly the same. For the dispersion in water, all PVAc, PVAc–OMMT-A, PVAc–OMMT-B, and PVAc–OMMT-C, their dispersion was much better, while PVAc–OMMT-D and PVAc–OMMT-E were not. Therefore, on behalf of all PVAc, only PVAc-A was chosen and tested by DMA, and all PVAc–OMMT, including PVAc–OMM-A, PVAc–OMMT-B, PVAc–OMMT-C, PVAc–OMMT-D, and PVAc–OMMT-E were tested by DMA. From Figure 1, we can obtain the elastic modulus (E′, MPa), loss modulus (E″, MPa), loss tangent (tan δ), and glass transition temperature (Tg, °C) of PVAc and PVAc–OMMT. Tg and tan δ are two important indices for damping materials. tan δ determines the damping properties good or bad, and Tg the applied temperature and frequency range of damping materials. On a DMA spectrum, Tg is always the temperature corresponding to the maximum loss tangent. Moreover, for the damping materials, its effective damping temperature zone (Ζ0, °C) can be calculated by: Z0=Tg±(10-15) Figure 1.
DMA spectra: (a) PVAc–A, (b) PVAc–OMMT–A, (c) PVAc–OMMT–B, (d) PVAc–OMMT–C, (e) PVAc–OMMT–D, (f) PVAc–OMMT–E.

So for our synthesized PVAc and PVAc–OMMT, their related results obtained from DMA spectra are given in Table 1. Table 1.
DMA data
PVAc-A PVAc–OMMT
A B C D E
E′max (MPa) 32 39 38 31 38 27
E″max (MPa) 71 60 57 84 99 11
tan δmax 76 38 28 63 234 1
Tg (°C) 72 15 15 15 23 72
Z0 (°C) 72 ± (10 − 15) 15 ± (10 − 15) 15 ± (10 − 15) 15 ± (10 − 15) 23 ± (10 − 15) 72 ± (10 − 15)

Obviously, the different synthesis processes and OMMT had significant effect on Tg and Ζ0, and unstable but significant effect on others. OMMT is a layered silicate. There are dipoles and ion-static electricity in its layers. Its surface has no chemical group which can directly combine with PVAc. In our synthesized PVAc–OMMT, OMMT was fully exfoliated into layers or sheets of nano-particles. They could not effectively restrict the movement of PVAc molecules. The density of the network formed by them was lower, and they hardly aggregated in PVAc matrix, so it had little contribution to improve the modulus. For tan δ, it indicates that the loss caused by the internal friction between macromolecules resulting from the large or small molecular chains’ movement. On one hand, OMMT makes the effective volume of polymer matrix become smaller, this is also called the volume effect; and on the other hand, the dynamic loss of rigid OMMT layers is far less than polymer matrix. With the increase of OMMT, this internal friction will become greater, and then lead tan δ to increase. In our synthesis, OMMT was 2% of VAc, it was a reasonable addition, but from process A–E, the water weight in the reaction decreased, respectively, were 250, 200, 150, 100, and 50 g. In other words, with the decrease of water in the synthesis from A–E, OMMT content increased, so combined the effects brought by the different synthesis processes and OMMT together, the modulus and tan δ of PVAc–OMMT, comparing with PVAc–A, sometimes they were higher while sometimes they were lower. These variation trends were not intuitive and stable.

In our DMA test, the samples were circular films, respectively, prepared by PVAc and PVAc–OMMT. In these films, polymer chains enter into OMMT layers: (1) their movement is limited by the space, and (2) the molecular chains in the layers will interact with organics or MMT, this interaction can bind the polymer chains, make the resistance of chains’ movement increase, and this is a glass relaxation movement, a non-cooperative movement related to glass transition, so for these nano-composites, the glass transition will happen at a slightly higher temperature.27,28 When the glass transition is ongoing, the interaction between OMMT and polymer matrix will limit the polymer chains’ movement near their interface. In the thin layers or under sandwich restriction, the transformation of these macromolecules will differ from their ontological status. They will shift their behavior and demonstrate the properties of both polymer and ceramics.27,29 As described above, MMT or OMMT will enhance polymer’s Tg, even the glass transition of some systems will disappear. But for our Tg, it was not the case, though its variation was very obvious. PVAc–OMMT-A’s, PVAc–OMMT-B’s, and PVAc–OMMT-C’s Tg all was 15°C, PVAc–OMMT-D’s Tg was 23°C, they all were much lower than PVAc-A’s 72°C, and PVAc–OMMT-E’s Tg increased to 72°C again, so their Ζ0 was different, too. These phenomena showed that Tg of PVAc–OMMT was seriously affected by the different synthesis processes and OMMT. For PVAc–OMMT-E, it was the exception. Maybe its specific synthesis process and OMMT brought combined effect on Tg, so it increased to 72°C again. This unusual phenomenon about Tg may be because the polymer chains are with great rigidity and great volume, as OMMT layers are also rigid flat-chips. These two molecules with very different shape, very different rigidity, and with considerable size, pack together, make the free volume of the system increase, and then reduce Tg.30 Also as the same to modulus and tan δ, the different synthesis processes and OMMT brought combined effect on the variation of Tg. In other words, OMMT in the synthesis could lower Tg of PVAc, the low temperature resistance of PVAc could be greatly improved by OMMT, so PVAc–OMMT could be applied in more harsh or much lower temperature conditions than PVAc.

And also from Figure 1, we can find out that the cold crystallization phenomenon appeared on these DMA spectra. PVAc is a homogeneous amorphous linear polymer. Although OMMT was added and polymerized with VAc in the synthesis, it did not change the structure. As described in our previous work,16–20 the absorption bands on Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy spectra of PVAc–OMMT were stacked by those of OMMT and PVAc. Neither new absorption bands formed, nor did existing absorption bands disappear, and no chemical bond existed between them, but only physical adsorptions or secondary bonds, so PVAc–OMMT was the same to PVAc, also a homogeneous amorphous linear polymer. Under different temperatures, the homogeneous amorphous linear polymer generally experiences three different mechanical states: glass state, high elastic state, and viscous flow state. But for some amorphous polymers which possess the crystallization ability cannot crystalline at the beginning because of inappropriate conditions, they are more likely to appear the cold crystallization above Tg when temperature is rising, as a result, E′ will recover and increase after falling around the end of glass transition until the crystallization phase is melt, then it will sharply fall (Figure 2). Obviously, as shown in Figure 1, PVAc and PVAc–OMMT appeared the cold crystallization. This has very important practical significance and can make materials’ structure to easily control in processing and molding.31,32 Figure 2.
Cold crystallization.

From the above results and analysis, we know that with the temperature rising, both PVAc and PVAc–OMMT went through the glass transition, the cold crystallization, and then melt into the viscous flow. During these phases, E′ was varying all the time. From the variation, we can learn their kinetics, including the glass transition kinetics and the cold crystallization kinetics. In glass state, molecular thermal motion energy is very low, it only has a small motor unit, molecular chains and segments all are in the frozen state, the free volume is small, and the reaction and diffusion rate are very slow, almost to 0. In high-elastic state, the movement of molecular segments is inspired, the free volume is larger, macromolecular movement can occur, the molecular diffusion rate increases, and the reaction rate is faster. The glass transition occurs from glass to high elastic state, and accompanying with this transition, many physical and mechanical properties of polymers change dramatically, such as specific volume, specific heat, expansion coefficient, thermal conductivity, refractive index, strain, and modulus, they all will appear mutation or discontinuous change, so glass transition directly impacts on the use and technological properties of polymers. The cold crystallization, as defined above, is the imperfect performance of polymer crystallization, and it is exothermic. For polymers which are difficult to crystalline, the movement capacity of molecular chains increases before the crystallization is melt, and then the imperfect crystals are further improved, like polyethylene terephthalate. In the crystallization, macromolecular chains arrange in neat and intermolecular forces increase, thus the density, stiffness, tensile strength, hardness, heat resistance, anti-soluble, air-tightness, chemical resistance, and other properties of polymers increase, but those depending on the molecular segment movement, such as flexibility, break elongation, and impact strength decrease. These changes in glass transition and cold crystallization can be expressed in the form of quantitative description, which will be used to control or optimize the glass transition and cold crystallization temperatures of polymers in their synthesis and processing. Therefore, in this article, referring with the methods and ideas from He et al.,21–24 the glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics were quantitatively analyzed by the Agrawal integral equation.

For the kinetics, the mechanism function is always expressed as: G(a)=Aβ∫T0Te-ERTdT where a is the relative elastic modulus calculated by: a=Eonset'-E'Eonset'-Eoffset' where, in a phase, Eonset' is the onset elastic modulus, Eoffset' the offset elastic modulus, and E′ an elastic modulus.
The Agrawal approximate equation is:33 ∫T0Te-EaRTdT=RT2Ea[1-2(RTEa)1-5(RTEa)2]e-EaRT
Combining the above two equations together, the Agrawal integral equation is written as: ln[G(a)T2]=ln{ARβEa[1-(RTEa)1-5(RTEa)2]}-EaRT
For the general reaction temperature and most of Ea, the relationship among Ea, R, and T are: EaRT>>1;1-(RTEa)≈1;1-5(RTEa)≈1.
So, the Agrawal integral equation is simplified as: ln[G(a)T2]=ln(ARβEa)-EaRT
The relationship between ln[G(a)T2] and 1T will be linear if with a suitable G(a), then Ea can be calculated from the linear slope, A can be calculated from the linear intercept.

In the above equations, T is the temperature, R the universal gas constant, i.e., 8.314 J·(mol K)−1, β the heating rate, i.e., 5°C min−1, Ea the activation energy, and A the frequency factor. Then, according to the simplified Agrawal integral equation, T and a in the glass transition and cold crystallization were linear fit by the trial-and-error method. Based on the linearly dependent coefficient (r), the glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics of PVAc-A and PVAc–OMMT were obtained as given in Table 2. For the glass transition, the kinetics mechanism functions of PVAc-A, PVAc–OMMT-D, and PVAc–OMMT-E were the Zhuralev–Lesokin–Tempelman equation, its mechanism was three-dimensional (3D) diffusion; that of PVAc–OMMT-A was the Avrami–Erofeev equation, its mechanism was random nucleation and subsequent growth, the reaction order (n) was 4; and those of PVAc–OMMT-B and PVAc–OMMT-C were the Jander equation, their mechanism were two-dimensional diffusion, and 3D, respectively. For the cold crystallization, the kinetics mechanism function of PVAc-A and all PVAc–OMMT was the Zhuralev–Lesokin–Tempelman equation, and its mechanism was 3D diffusion. These indicated that the glass transition of PVAc-A and all PVAc–OMMT was similar, and their cold crystallization was the same. Table 2.
Glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics
T (°C) G(a) Linear fit equation r Ea (kJ mol−1) A (min−1)
PVAc-A 65–78 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −6681.8X + 81.691 0.9768 55.55 1.00 × 1040
78–105 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −2647.1X + 18.263 0.9586 22.01 1.13 × 1012
PVAc–OMMT A 7–29 [-ln-1-a]4 Y = −206.7X + 5.9233 0.9969 1.72 3.86 × 105
61–95 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −2515.2X + 20.545 0.9971 20.91 1.05 × 1013
B 7–28 [(1-a)-12]2 Y = −59.277X − 4.4839 0.9950 0.49 3.35
51–87 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −2074X + 18.975 0.9957 17.24 1.81 × 1012
C 5–25 [(1+a)13-1]2 Y = −37.344X − 7.8737 0.9718 0.31 0.07
32–84 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −734.07X + 3.2278 0.9973 6.10 9.26 × 104
D 11–35 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −265.07X + 2.0713 0.9973 2.20 1.05 × 104
35–65 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −1058.1X + 11.365 0.9662 8.80 4.56 × 108
E 43–97 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −1170.9X + 7.3406 0.9940 9.73 9.03 × 106
102–155 [(1-a)-13-1]2 Y = −3467.9X + 14.183 0.9739 28.83 2.50 × 1010

In these kinetic parameters, G(a) was the kinetics mechanism function. It illustrated the glass transition and cold crystallization processes of PVAc or PVAc–OMMT. If their G(a) were different, their linear fit equation, r, Ea, A, and n were different, too. Ea was the minimum energy required from a reactant molecule to an activated molecule in a chemical reaction. It was the different energies between the onset and the offset of glass transition and cold crystallization. A was a constant determined by the reaction essence, and had nothing to do with the reaction temperature and concentration in the system. It was one of the important reaction kinetic parameters.

In addition, the linear relationship between lnA and Ea is named as the kinetic compensation effect. It is a main characteristic in kinetics, explaining that A partly compensates to the change of Ea. The equation34 is: lnA=KEa+Q where K and Q are the kinetic compensation effect parameters which can be calculated by linear fit between Ea and A. Then, the kinetic compensation effects of glass transition and cold crystallization for PVAc and PVAc–OMMT were obtained as given in Table 3. Because the kinetic compensation effect parameters have nothing to do with the experimental factors, the kinetic compensation effect equations could clearly explain the properties of glass transition and cold crystallization for PVAc and PVAc–OMMT, and also were their theoretical expression. Table 3.
Kinetic compensation effect equations
T (°C) K Q r Kinetic compensation effect equation
PVAc-A 65–78 1.6801 −0.4269 0.9987 lnA = 1.6801Ea − 0.4269
78–105 1.4108 −2.0516 0.9919 lnA = 1.4108Ea − 2.0516
PVAc–OMMT A 7–29 8.7104 −2.3063 0.9506 lnA = 8.7104Ea − 2.3063
61–95 1.544 −1.8848 0.9969 lnA = 1.544Ea − 1.8848
B 7–28 9.2316 −2.6505 0.9637 lnA = 9.2316Ea − 2.6505
51–87 1.7636 −1.9109 0.9959 lnA = 1.7636Ea − 1.9109
C 5–25 7.7795 −2.9063 0.9670 lnA = 7.7795Ea − 2.9063
32–84 2.3582 −2.2336 0.9572 lnA = 2.3582Ea − 2.2336
D 11–35 5.2392 −1.7851 0.9819 lnA = 5.2392Ea − 1.7851
35–65 2.5417 −1.9853 0.9916 lnA = 2.5417Ea − 1.9853
E 43–97 1.9752 −2.2683 0.9665 lnA = 1.9752Ea − 2.2683
102–155 0.9372 −2.3586 0.9941 lnA = 0.9372Ea − 2.3586

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, PVAc–OMMT was synthesized by VAc and OMMT through different processes. Different synthesis processes and OMMT had significant effect on the dynamic mechanical properties. They brought combined effect on the modulus, loss tangent, and Tg. OMMT in the synthesis could lower Tg of PVAc, and improved PVAc’s low temperature resistance, so PVAc–OMMT could be applied in more harsh or much lower temperature conditions than PVAc. PVAc and PVAc–OMMT all were homogeneous amorphous linear polymers and they all appeared the cold crystallization phenomenon on DMA spectra. Their glass transition and cold crystallization kinetics were first analyzed using the Agrawal integral equation. The kinetic parameters, including G(a), the linear fit equation, r, Ea, A, the mechanism, n, and the kinetic compensation effect equation, were obtained.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
